conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I know the answer
You know how to sing
He knows how to swim
We know how to dance
You know how to cook
They know how to play

tenses.description: Used to describe actions happening now, general truths, or habitual actions. This is the most commonly used tense in Italian.

conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I knew the answer
You knew how to sing
He knew how to swim
We knew how to dance
You knew how to cook
They knew how to play

tenses.description: Used to describe ongoing, repeated, or habitual actions in the past. Also used for background information in storytelling.

conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I will know the answer tomorrow
You will know how to sing
He will know how to swim
We will know how to dance
You will know how to cook
They will know how to play

tenses.description: Used to express future actions, predictions, or intentions. Often used with time expressions like 'domani' (tomorrow) or 'la settimana prossima' (next week).

conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I have known the answer
You have known how to sing
He has known how to swim
We have known how to dance
You have known how to cook
They have known how to play

tenses.description: Used to express completed actions in the past that have a connection to the present. This is the most common past tense in spoken Italian.

conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I knew the answer
You knew how to sing
He knew how to swim
We knew how to dance
You knew how to cook
They knew how to play

tenses.description: Used primarily in formal and literary Italian to narrate completed past events. Also used in southern Italy in spoken language.

conjugations.exampleSentence: Io avevo saputo la risposta prima che piovesse
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I had known the answer before it rained

conjugations.exampleSentence: Tu avevi saputo cantare prima che venissi
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: You had known how to sing before I came

conjugations.exampleSentence: Lui aveva saputo nuotare prima che arrivassimo
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: He had known how to swim before we arrived

conjugations.exampleSentence: Noi avevamo saputo ballare prima che facesse buio
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: We had known how to dance before it got dark

conjugations.exampleSentence: Voi avevate saputo cucinare prima della chiusura
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: You had known how to cook before closing

conjugations.exampleSentence: Loro avevano saputo giocare prima dello spettacolo
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: They had known how to play before the show

tenses.description: Used to express actions that were completed before another past action. Often used in storytelling to establish a sequence of past events.

conjugations.exampleSentence: Appena ebbi saputo la risposta, piovve
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: As soon as I had known the answer, it rained
As soon as you had known how to sing, I came
As soon as he had known how to swim, we arrived

conjugations.exampleSentence: Appena avemmo saputo ballare, fece buio
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: As soon as we had known how to dance, it got dark

conjugations.exampleSentence: Appena aveste saputo cucinare, il ristorante chiuse
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: As soon as you had known how to cook, the restaurant closed

conjugations.exampleSentence: Appena ebbero saputo giocare, lo spettacolo cominciò
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: As soon as they had known how to play, the show began

tenses.description: Used in formal and literary Italian to express an action that was completed immediately before another past action. Rarely used in modern Italian.

conjugations.exampleSentence: Io avrò saputo la risposta domani
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I will have known the answer tomorrow
You will have known how to sing
He will have known how to swim
We will have known how to dance
You will have known how to cook
They will have known how to play

tenses.description: Used to express actions that will be completed before another future action. Often used with time expressions like 'domani' (tomorrow).

conjugations.exampleSentence: Io saprei la risposta se avessi tempo
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I would know the answer if I had time
You would know how to sing
He would know how to swim
We would know how to dance
You would know how to cook
They would know how to play

tenses.description: Used to express hypothetical situations, polite requests, or actions that would happen under certain conditions. Often used with 'se' (if) clauses.

conjugations.exampleSentence: Io avrei saputo la risposta se avessi potuto
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I would have known the answer if I could have
You would have known how to sing
He would have known how to swim
We would have known how to dance
You would have known how to cook
They would have known how to play

tenses.description: Used to express hypothetical past actions or regrets about things that didn't happen. Often used with 'se' (if) clauses referring to the past.

conjugations.exampleSentence: È necessario che io sappia la risposta
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I must know the answer
I want you to know how to sing

conjugations.exampleSentence: È necessario che lui sappia nuotare
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: He must know how to swim

conjugations.exampleSentence: È necessario che noi sappiamo ballare
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: We must know how to dance

conjugations.exampleSentence: È necessario che voi sappiate cucinare
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: You must know how to cook

conjugations.exampleSentence: È necessario che loro sappiano giocare
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: They must know how to play

tenses.description: Used in dependent clauses after certain expressions of opinion, doubt, emotion, or necessity. Often used after 'è necessario che', 'voglio che', etc.

conjugations.exampleSentence: Era necessario che io sapessi la risposta
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I had to know the answer
I wanted you to know how to sing

conjugations.exampleSentence: Era necessario che lui sapesse nuotare
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: He had to know how to swim

conjugations.exampleSentence: Era necessario che noi sapessimo ballare
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: We had to know how to dance

conjugations.exampleSentence: Era necessario che voi sapeste cucinare
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: You had to know how to cook

conjugations.exampleSentence: Era necessario che loro sapessero giocare
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: They had to know how to play

tenses.description: Used in formal and literary Italian after the same triggers as present subjunctive, but referring to past events. Rarely used in modern spoken Italian.

conjugations.exampleSentence: È necessario che io abbia saputo la risposta
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I must have known the answer

conjugations.exampleSentence: Voglio che tu abbia saputo cantare
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I want you to have known how to sing

conjugations.exampleSentence: È necessario che lui abbia saputo nuotare
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: He must have known how to swim

conjugations.exampleSentence: È necessario che noi abbiamo saputo ballare
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: We must have known how to dance

conjugations.exampleSentence: È necessario che voi abbiate saputo cucinare
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: You must have known how to cook

conjugations.exampleSentence: È necessario che loro abbiano saputo giocare
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: They must have known how to play

tenses.description: Used in dependent clauses after expressions of doubt, emotion, or necessity when referring to a completed action in the past.

conjugations.exampleSentence: Era necessario che io avessi saputo la risposta
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I had to have known the answer

conjugations.exampleSentence: Volevo che tu avessi saputo cantare
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I wanted you to have known how to sing

conjugations.exampleSentence: Era necessario che lui avesse saputo nuotare
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: He had to have known how to swim

conjugations.exampleSentence: Era necessario che noi avessimo saputo ballare
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: We had to have known how to dance

conjugations.exampleSentence: Era necessario che voi aveste saputo cucinare
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: You had to have known how to cook

conjugations.exampleSentence: Era necessario che loro avessero saputo giocare
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: They had to have known how to play

tenses.description: Used in formal and literary Italian after the same triggers as other subjunctive tenses, but referring to actions completed before another past action.
Used to give commands, orders, or instructions. Only exists for the second person (tu, noi, voi). The subject pronoun is omitted.

conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I want to know the answer
I must know how to sing
I can know how to swim

tenses.description: The base form of the verb, used after modal verbs, prepositions, and in many other constructions.

conjugations.exampleSentence: Dopo aver saputo la risposta, ho studiato
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: After having known the answer, I studied

conjugations.exampleSentence: Prima di aver saputo cantare, ho lavorato
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: Before having known how to sing, I worked

conjugations.exampleSentence: Dopo aver saputo nuotare, ho cenato
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: After having known how to swim, I had dinner

tenses.description: Used to express actions that were completed before another action. Often used after modal verbs in the past.

conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: A knowledgeable person
The knowledgeable work
The knowledgeable machine

tenses.description: Used as an adjective or in progressive constructions. In modern Italian, it's mainly used as an adjective.

conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I have known the answer
She has known how to sing
They have known how to swim

tenses.description: Used to form compound tenses and as an adjective. Must agree in gender and number with the subject.

conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I am knowing the answer
You are knowing how to sing
He is knowing how to swim

tenses.description: Used to express ongoing actions, often with 'stare' to form the present continuous tense.

conjugations.exampleSentence: Avendo saputo la risposta, ho studiato
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: Having known the answer, I studied
Having known how to sing, she rested
Having known how to swim, they had dinner

tenses.description: Used to express actions that were completed before another action. Rarely used in modern Italian.
